comments.author: XCyclonusX

comments.text:
+XCyclonusX Here's a more concrete explanation of why 0! = 1. 

We know that there are n! ways to arrange n distinct objects. We'll use 
this fact later.

So, let's say you have n objects, but you only want to arrange r of them. 
How many ways are there to do that? It turns out the answer, which is 
another widely-used formula, is n! / (n - r)!.

To see this, say we have 7 objects and are arranging 3 of them. For the 
first object, we have 7 choices. For the second, we have 6 choices, and for 
the third, we have 5 choices. Therefore, there are 7x6x5 ways to arrange 3 
objects from a group of 7. This is equal to 7! / 4! because of the 
cancelling and stuff.

So, when r is a positive integer less than or equal to n, there are n! / (n 
- r)! ways to arrange those r objects. 

What happens when r = n? Then the question is, we have n objects, and how 
many ways are there to arrange all n of them? According to the formula, 
there are n! / (n - n)! = n! / 0! ways to do so.

But we already know the answer. There are n! ways to arrange n objects. 
Therefore:

n! / 0! = n!

Hence, 0! must be equal to 1. It can't be equal to any other number. It 
also can't be undefined due to that equality.


Also, 1 isn't a prime number. It's not prime by definition. But the 
definition I'm talking about isn't the one you know. I'm talking about the 
more general definition of what a prime element is, and prime numbers in 
the integers are just a special case of these general prime elements. 
University-level abstract algebra is required to fully explain what I'm 
talking about, but just know that 1 is not prime by definition.

comments.text:
We can also look at re-ordering objects without reverting back to their 
original position. So basically, we're doing factorial - 1.

5! - 1 = 120 - 1 = 119
4! - 1 = 24 - 1 = 23
3! - 1 = 6 - 1 = 5
2! - 1 = 2 - 1 = 1
1! - 1 = 1 - 1 = 0
0! - 1 = 1 - 1 = 0

And that holds true, because there are indeed 0 ways to re-order 0 or 1 
objects from their starting position. If you have 1 object on a table, 
there is no other way to sort it other than the way it's already sorted. If 
you have 0 objects on the table, there is no other way to sort them.

However, if 0! would be 0, then suddenly we get this oddity:

0! - 1 = 0 - 1 = 0

Obviously 0 - 1 is not 0. Hence, 0! must be 1.﻿

comments.author: nailuj100

comments.text:
+nailuj100 You are right in that there is a lot of vacuous truths involved. 
However, there is only one permutation of the empty set.

If you wish, we could define n! to be the number of permutations of a set 
containing n elements. If you've ever taken abstract algebra and seen the 
symmetric groups, this will come as no surprise.


The permutations of a set S are simply the one-to-one and onto functions 
from S to itself. For the empty set ∅, we can use vacuous truths to show 
that there exists a unique one-to-one and onto function from ∅ to ∅.  This 
would show that there is one permutation of a set with 0 elements and would 
suggest that 0! should indeed be 1.


We define f: ∅ → ∅.  Since ∅ has no elements, we don't have to specify 
where any elements go.


In order to prove that f is well-defined, we just have to show that if x = 
y are elements of ∅, then f(x) = f(y).  This is vacuously true, so f is 
well-defined.

In order to prove that f is one-to-one, we just have to show that if x and 
y are distinct elements of ∅, then f(x) and f(y) are distinct elements 
of ∅.  Again, this is vacuously true, so f is one-to-one.

In order to prove that f is onto, we just have to show that if y is an 
element of ∅, then there exists an element x of ∅ so that f(x) = y.  This 
vacuous truth shows f is onto.

In order to show that there is only one permutation of ∅, we have to show 
that for any other permutation g of ∅, f = g.  To show this, we just need 
to show that if x is an element of ∅, then f(x) = g(x).  Again, this is 
vacuously true, and so there is only one unique permutation of ∅.

I guess the natural question would be... can't we also prove that if x is 
an element of ∅, then f(x) does not equal g(x)?  The answer is yes, we 
could prove that.

However, in order to show that two functions f, g: S → T are distinct, you 
must show that there exists an element x of S such that f(x) does not equal 
g(x).  You cannot prove this statement for S = ∅ because you would be 
required to prove that there is an element in ∅, which is false.

So even though the functions disagree on every element of the empty set, 
they also agree on every element of the empty set, so they are the same 
function and are not different functions.

+Adam -亚当- Well supposed you have a set with three elements. The number of 
permutations or ways we can order them is 3! or 6 different ways. Lets

{3,2,1}, {2,3,1},and {3,1,2}. Right? A permutation as a bijective function 
means that f:{1,2,3}→ {1,2,3} meaning we are mapping from the same set of 
elements to another same set of elements...but we can change the order such 
that 1,2,3 ↦3,1,2 if put in that function we would have a one to one 
correspondence. 1 maps to 3, 2 maps to 1 and 3 maps to 2 with all numbers 
accounted for and not mapped more than once. It literally is like taking a 
function of f(1)= 3 , f(2)=1 and f(3) = 2 and as you know a function has 
only one input and only one output. That is a bijection from set S to set 
S. :)

comments.text:
Um...I don't see any proof. I see a lot of evidence, but nothing actually 
got proven here. 
As was demonstrated, the pattern as it was described here does not work. 
Not only that, but no law or definition of factorials says that this 
pattern must be complete all the way to zero. If they do, I'm calling those 
laws or definitions out. Aside from the complicated math which was casually 
left unexplained here, all these rules for determining factorials lean on 
each other in suggestion that 0!=1. One wasn't even mentioned when the 
suggestion began to form (I still remain entirely unconvinced that a proof 
exists at all). The one I refer to is the classical definition, which is 
always used to introduce factorials. This is that 
n!=n•(n-1)•(n-2)•...•3•2•1. Even this definition is circumstantial, and 
must be bypassed when determining numbers such as 3!. But by this method of 
finding factorials, which is taught as a default, one *MUST* have a number 
that is both positive and greater than 6. 

If you then get down to a better and more generic definition, which is that 
n! is n multiplied by all non-zero integers less than itself, and n>0, you 
run into trouble once more. First when calculating 1!, because 1 has no 
non-zero integers less than it. This is not covered well in the original 
model either, although it is always assumed that one can make the logical 
jump to find that 1!=1. 1! cannot be calculated unless you choose to make a 
special case specificaly for 1!, dictating that 1! Is equal to 1•1, or 
simply 1 if you don't feel multiplication is necessary in a 
multiplication-based function. If you don't specify this case, you have no 
way at all of knowing what 1! is, because as I previously stated, the rules 
(without relying on other *PATTERNS*) do not give a method for calculation.

The problem with 0! should be obvious by now, as it is exactly the same as 
the problem with 1!. There is no method for the calculation of 0! which 
does not rely on mehods whose reliability may or may not extend all the way 
to 0!. So once again, we have an answer defined by flawed logic, which is 
accepted *UNIVERSALLY* in the mathematical community. I have a problem with 
that.

how it *RELIABLY* proves both 1! and 0!, feel free to pm me on youtube or
